messageBody:
Working on writing an article for an upcoming issue of
a magazine targeted towards CIOs. Here is the basic
thought:

The vast majority of CIOs have been wreckless in their
thinking about outsourcing. The notion of sending work
primarily to India is minimally irresponsible. CIOs
have the fiduciary duty to protect the integrity of
their systems and the health and welfare of existing
employees.

The responsible CIOs have taken steps that address the
India movement. For example, the CIO of Phoenix Life
took the initiative to build their own outsourcing
facility in Bangalore India instead of giving it over
to a third party. They did not underestimate the need
for "employees" to do work instead of third parties.

Other CIOs that have adapted Agile approaches realize
that people interaction is more important than
processes and tools. They figured out that outsourcing
to locations where interaction with existing staff is
easier makes the most sense. The really smart CIOs
have looked at smaller countries in the same time zone
as their employees. For example, there are outsourcing
companies in Barbados and Trinidad.

The Agile CIO also understands that his/her own
employees need to periodically travel in order to form
a viable partnership. Choosing countries that have
direct flights from major airports such as JFK, Miami,
etc are responsible. Likewise choosing countries where
culture is similar to US/UK is also responsible.

Ignoring the fact that the world is changing where
terrorist activities are prevalent, choosing countries
where this will not jeopardize the business is vital.
Imagine how many strategies are at risk if Pakistan
decides to fight India. One could academically argue
that maybe Trinidad would fight Barbados but this
would be silly.

CIOs simply need to be more responsible...
